node.title: Overlooked Stories
node.alt: A photo by Isaac Wright during a climb on the Queensboro Bridge.
node.description: Today we look at stories from 2021 that didnâ€™t receive as much attention as they deserved.
node.content: ["How does a New York Times story get overlooked? Often, it\u2019s a case of bad luck. We publish a great piece of writing, then some major news occupies everyone\u2019s attention for the day. Or editors make a last-minute change that cuts an article from this newsletter or moves it off the front page.", "As we did at the end of last year, the Morning team reached out to editors around the Times newsroom to ask for their favorite articles \u2014 and, this year, podcast episodes \u2014 that may have flown under the radar.", "If there\u2019s one thing that bonds the stories in this collection, it\u2019s that they remain relevant after a year in which so much of our world seemed to change. \u201cIt ran inside the paper,\u201d one editor said about a story he sent us, \u201cbut it has aged well.\u201d", "Enjoy these 25 great stories.", "1. Isaac Wright\u2019s PTSD therapy was climbing. His climbing made him a fugitive.", "2. A day in the life of a pro tennis ball kid.", "3. This conversation will change how you think about thinking.", "4. Democrats loved Iowa. Iowa stopped loving them back.", "5. The beach buskers, bait sellers and heladeros that make a New York City summer.", "6. There are parts of the West where the stars shine so bright they light up the sand. But when the world is on fire, all you see is smoke.", "7. Building homes for the 21st century: \u201cIt\u2019s cool as hell. And it\u2019s modern, and it\u2019s noncombustible.\u201d", "8. An easy way to prevent heat deaths: Plant more trees.", "9. To power the earth, some start-ups are looking to the energy that powers the sun.", "10. An assault left a Venezuelan girl pregnant. Her mother and teacher were arrested over her abortion.", "11. The Ethiopian government rounded up people of Tigrayan descent \u2014 young men and women, mothers with children, the elderly.", "12. People predicted the pandemic would kill cities. They were wrong.", "13. Ten photographers showed us how America dresses.", "14. Sophie made music that sounded like joy. \u201cIt\u2019s unashamed. It\u2019s proud. It\u2019s loud.\u201d", "15. When the local video store went out of business, he built his own \u2014 in his basement.", "16. They looked at Bitcoin\u2019s technology and saw a new way to build the internet.", "17. Dave Eggers can see the tech dystopia on our horizon.", "18. We were promised self-driving cars. What\u2019s taking so long?", "19. Qualified immunity protects police officers. Two lawyers debated whether that\u2019s a good thing.", "20. A novel made the editor of Vanity Fair ask: \u201cWhat are the limits of humanity?\u201d", "21. What parenting in a pandemic sounds like. \u201cI can\u2019t escape these kids. They eat all day long.\u201d", "22. A discovery in low gravity: For the first time in his life, he could stand.", "23. Sydney McLaughlin broke her own world record. We tracked it step by step.", "24. Was that million-dollar basketball card signed by Mom?", "25. Goodbye to a Yankee farmer, the ghost of Exit 8.", "\u201cA writer uniquely attuned to the disorder and fragmentation of our times.\u201d Michiko Kakutani remembers Joan Didion.", "Omicron is not a story about the failure of vaccines or a sign that Covid will forever dominate our lives, Daniela Lamas argues.", "Politico rounded up the year\u2019s worst political predictions.", "Great find: He paid $30 for a drawing. It could be worth millions.", "Yassification: Catherine was great. But was she a girl boss?", "Quiz time: Have you taken the Great News Quiz of 2021 yet?", "Advice from Wirecutter: Consider a new cellphone plan or carrier.", "Lives Lived: Jean-Marc Vall\u00e9e, the director behind the film \u201cDallas Buyers Club\u201d and the HBO show \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d was famous for a naturalistic and generous approach that brought out the best in those he worked with. He died at 58.", "Edward O. Wilson was a biologist and author who conducted pioneering work on biodiversity, insects and human nature. He died at 92.", "The editors of the Times Book Review read a lot of books every year. They also compile a lot of lists, and we\u2019re here to help you make sense of them.", "From 100 notable books \u2026: Fiction, memoirs, nonfiction or poetry \u2014 this list has it all.", "\u2026 to the top 10: The editors deliberate throughout the year to whittle the list of 100 down to 10.", "Critic\u2019s picks: The Times\u2019s book critics also make their own lists based on the books they reviewed throughout the year. (If you want to know how they get there, you can read their discussion.)", "Gift list: Books make for excellent gifts, and these 71 dazzling titles \u2014 including thrillers, cookbooks, photography collections and more \u2014 will delight any reader.", "The outside: We know not to judge a book by its cover, but some covers deserve praise. The Book Review\u2019s art director picked his favorites.", "Take leftover ham, saut\u00e9 onions and make irresistible bite-size sandwiches.", "The Metropolitan Museum of Art hopes to entice visitors with 150 Disney artifacts.", "\u201cWest Side Story\u201d used to be a musical told through movement. Now, The Times\u2019s dance critic writes, it\u2019s a musical \u201ctold through words. So many, many words.\u201d", "The pangram from Friday\u2019s Spelling Bee was flipbook.
